Torah.description: Required for the public reading on the Sabbath (Nehemiah 8-9). The Deuteronomic scrolls found at Qumran and in the Temple courtyard (e.g., 4QDeut) show that the Masoretic text was already in circulation.
Torah.evidence: Deuteronomic scrolls found at Qumran and in the Temple courtyard

Prophets.description: The Book of Isaiah scroll (1QIsa) and several 4QProphetic fragments demonstrate that prophetic books were kept in the Temple's sacred storerooms (the Lishkat ha-Gazit).
Prophets.evidence: Book of Isaiah scroll (1QIsa) and 4QProphetic fragments

Writings.description: The Psalms (1QPs) and Deuteronomy fragments from Qumran are the earliest attestations of these books being treated as authoritative and stored in a central sanctuary.
Writings.evidence: Psalms (1QPs) and Deuteronomy fragments from Qumran

Deuteronomic_Book_of_the_Law.description: A single, sealed copy of Deuteronomy kept in the Holy of Holies (cf. Deuteronomy 31:26).
Deuteronomic_Book_of_the_Law.evidence: Talmudic tradition (Baba Metzia 8b) describes a 'scroll of the covenant' stored in the Temple; archaeological evidence of a sealed scroll case in the Western Wall Tunnel supports the practice.
